case_name: Trustees of the Charity Fund Founded by Sir Sassoon David, Baronet of Bombay v. the respondent

facts.text: Civil Appeal No.396 of 1957 is an appeal from the Judgment and Order dated the 21st February, 1956, of the Bombay High Court in Income-tax Reference No. 32 of 1954.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No.396 of 1957. Appeal from the Judgment and Order dated the 21st February, 1956, of the Bombay High Court in Income-tax Reference No. 32 of 1954.

facts.text: Certificate granted on September 19, 1956, by the High Court of Bombay under s. 66A(2) of the Indian Income Tax Act.

anchor.surface_text: This is an appeal brought on a certificate granted on September 19, 1956, by the High Court of Bombay under s. 66 A  2  of the Indian Income Tax Act  hereinafter referred to as the said Act   against its order dated February 21, 1956, in Income-tax Reference No. 32 of 1954

facts.text: Appellants are the trustees of a charity fund known as The Charity Fund Founded by Sir Sassoon David, Baronet of Bombay.

anchor.surface_text: answering in the negative two questions of law referred to it under s. 66 1  of the said Act at the instance of the appellants. The appellants are the trustees of a charity fund known as The Charity Fund Founded by Sir Sassoon David, Baronet of Bombay .

facts.text: Sir Sassoon David, Bart. and four other persons held securities of the value of Rs. 24,25,000 for the purpose of charity.

anchor.surface_text: The said Sir Sassoon David, Bart. and four other persons, who were holding certain securities of the value of Rs. 24,25,000 for the purpose of charity and had been applying the same for and towards charitable purposes, executed, on June 8, 1922, a Deed of Declaration of Trust

facts.text: Deed of Declaration of Trust executed on June 8, 1922.

anchor.surface_text: executed, on June 8, 1922, a Deed of Declaration of Trust declaring that the said trust fund would be held by them on trusts more specifically therein mentioned.

facts.text: Deed of Declaration of Trust registered on June 4, 1953, under the Bombay Public Trusts Act, 1950.

anchor.surface_text: This Deed of Declaration of Trust was, on June 4, 1953, registered under the Bombay Public Trusts Act, 1950.

facts.text: Trust fund invested in inter alia 3 1/2 Government Securities.

anchor.surface_text: The Trust fund had been invested by the trustees in inter alia  3 1/2 Government Securities.

facts.text: In the year 1930 a certificate was issued by the Income-tax Officer, A Ward, Bombay, authorising the Reserve Bank of India not to deduct tax at source on the interest on the securities.

anchor.surface_text: In the year 1930 a certificate was issued by the Income-tax Officer, A Ward, Bombay, whereby the Reserve Bank of India was authorised number to deduct at source the tax on the interest on the said securities so held by the trustees.

facts.text: The 1930 certificate was to enure till its cancellation.

anchor.surface_text: It was mentioned in the said certificate that it was to enure till its cancellation.

facts.text: In 1946 the 3 1/2 Government Securities were redeemed by the Government of India and converted into 3 Conversion Loan, 1946.

anchor.surface_text: In 1946 the 3 1/2 Government Securities were redeemed by the Government of India and were companyverted into 3 Con- version Loan, 1946.

facts.text: In February, 1948, the said certificate of exemption was cancelled.

anchor.surface_text: Accordingly in February, 1948, the said certificate of exemption was cancelled, as the securities companyered thereby had been redeemed by the Government.

facts.text: Income-tax Officer, Bombay Refund Circle refused to issue fresh certificate of exemption for 3 Conversion Loan, 1946 on ground income not exempt under s.4(3)(i).

anchor.surface_text: The trustees thereupon asked for a fresh certificate of exemption from the Income-tax Officer, Bombay Refund Circle in respect of the 3 Conversion Loan, 1946. But the said Income-tax Officer refused to issue such certificate on the ground that the income from the trust fund in question was number exempt from taxation under s. 4 3  i  of the said Act

facts.text: Income-tax Officer, A-V Ward, Bombay started proceedings under s.34 for assessment years 1944-45 to 1947-48.

anchor.surface_text: Upon the fact of the withholding of the certificate by the Income-tax Officer, Refund Circle, being intimated to the Income-tax Officer, A-V Ward, Bombay, the latter Officer started proceedings against the appellants under s. 34 of the said Act in respect of the assessment years 1944-45 to 1947-48.

facts.text: Income-tax Officer started regular assessment proceedings for 1948-49 and succeeding years up to 1952-53.

anchor.surface_text: He also started regular proceedings for the assessment year 1948-49 and the succeeding years up to 1952- 53.

facts.text: Income-tax Officer assessed appellants for assessment years 1944-45 to 1952-53 holding income not exempt under s.4(3)(i).

anchor.surface_text: In the assessment proceedings for those nine years the Income-tax Officer took the view that the income from the trust fund was number exempt from taxation under s. 4 3  i  and accordingly he assessed the appellants for the first four assessment years  1944-45 to 1947-48  on the ground that the income for those years had escaped assessment.

facts.text: Appellate Assistant Commissioner confirmed the assessments.

anchor.surface_text: On appeal the Appellate Assistant Commissioner companyfirmed the said assessments.

facts.text: Income-tax Appellate Tribunal set aside assessments for 1944-45 to 1947-48 holding s.34 wrongly invoked.

anchor.surface_text: On further appeal by the appellants, the Income-tax Appellate Tribunal set aside the assessments for the first four years  1944-45 to 1947-48  holding that s. 34 had been wrongly invoked, for it was only a case of difference of opinion of one Income- tax Officer from his predecessor on the same set of facts.

facts.text: Tribunal upheld assessments for 1948-49 to 1952-53.

anchor.surface_text: As regards the assessments for the five years  1948-49 to 1952-53  the Tribunal upheld the decision of the Appellate Assistant Commissioner who had companyfirmed the assessments made by the Income-tax Officer.

facts.text: Tribunal referred two questions of law to High Court under s.66(1): 1. Whether trust property held wholly for religious or charitable purposes under s.4(3)(i)? 2. If not, whether held in part only?

anchor.surface_text: On application being made by the appellants, under s. 66 1  of the said Act, the Tribunal drew up a statement of case and referred two questions of law arising out of its order to the High Court for its opinion. The said questions are as follows - Whether the Trust property is held wholly for religious or charitable purposes within the meaning of section 4 3  i  of the Indian Income-tax Act ?

facts.text: Bombay High Court answered both questions in the negative.

anchor.surface_text: The said reference came up for hearing before the said High Court and both the referred questions were answered in the negative.

facts.text: High Court granted certificate of fitness for appeal to Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court, however, gave the appellants a certificate of fitness for appeal to this Court

facts.text: Clause 13 of the deed specifies trusts for six purposes: a) relief of poor Jewish or other community; b) hospitals/schools; c) relief of distress; d) animals; e) religion; f) other beneficial.

anchor.surface_text: Clause 13 of the said deed, on the true companystruction of which depends the answer to the referred questions, runs as follows- The Trust Fund shall be held by the Trustees upon the Trusts to apply the net income thereof after providing for all necessary expenses in relation to the management of the Trust Funds for all or any of the following purposes, that is to say,  a  the relief and benefit of the poor and indigent members of Jewish or any other companymunity of Bombay or other parts of India or of the world either by making payments to them in cash or providing them with food and clothes and or lodging or residential quarters or in giving education including scholarships to or setting them up in life or in such other manner as to the said Trustees may seem proper or

facts.text: First proviso to Clause 13: Trustees shall give preference to poor and indigent relations or members of family of Sir Sassoon David, Bart., including distant and collateral.

anchor.surface_text: Provided always that in applying the income as aforesaid the Trustees shall give preference to the poor and indigent relations or members of the family of the said Sir Sassoon David, Bart., including therein distant and companylateral relations

facts.text: Second proviso: Not less than half the income to be applied for benefit of Jewish Community of Bombay including relations of Sir Sassoon David, and Jewish objects.

anchor.surface_text: provided further that in the application of the income of the said Charitable Trust Fund the said Trustees for the time being shall observe the following proportions, viz. that number less than half the income of the said funds shall at all times be applied for the benefit of the members of the Jewish Community of Bombay only  including the relations of Sir Sassoon David, Bart. as aforesaid  and Jewish objects

facts.text: Supreme Court holds trust property held wholly for religious or charitable purposes under s.4(3)(i), income exempt.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion the income from the trust properties companyes within the scope of s. 4 3  i  and is, therefore, entitled to exemption. Therefore the negative answer given by the High Court to question No. I cannot be supported and that question should be answered in the affirmative.
under s. 66 A  2  of the Indian Income Tax Act  hereinafter referred to as the said Act

under s. 4 3  i  of the said Act which, at the material time, was as follows- 4 1   2  Any income, profits or gains falling with-in the following classes shall number be included in total income of the person receiving them- Any income, derived from property held under trust or other legal obligation wholly for religious or charitable purposes, and in the case of property so held in part only for such purposes, the income applied, or finally set apart for application, thereto

It was companyceded before the High Court- and it has number been disputed before us-that if there was numberhing else in this clause, then each of these six purposes would have to be upheld as a charitable purpose involving an element of public utility

issues.text: Whether the Trust property is held wholly for religious or charitable purposes within the meaning of section 4 3  i  of the Indian Income-tax Act ?

anchor.surface_text: Whether the Trust property is held wholly for religious or charitable purposes within the meaning of section 4 3  i  of the Indian Income-tax Act ?

issues.text: If the answer to question 1 is in the negative, whether the trust property is held in part only for religious or charitable purposes ?

anchor.surface_text: If the answer to question  1  is in the negative, whether the trust property is held in part only for religious or charitable purposes ?

issues.text: Whether the provisos in clause 13 requiring preference to relations or members of the family of Sir Sassoon David, Bart. affect the validity of the trust as one held wholly for charitable purposes involving an element of public utility under section 4(3)(i)?

anchor.surface_text: A perusal of cl. 13 of the deed shows that the trust fund is declared to be held by the trustees upon trusts to apply the net income thereof for all or any of the six purposes enumerated therein. It was conceded before the High Court- and it has not been disputed before us-that if there was nothing else in this clause, then each of these six purposes would have to be upheld as a charitable purpose involving an element of public utility

issues.text: Whether the primary class test from In re Koettgen's Will Trusts applies to determine the public charitable nature of the trust despite provisos giving preference to a sub-class?

anchor.surface_text: The case of In re Koettgans Will Trusts  1  appears to us, on the facts, to be more in point... Applying this test, there can be no question- indeed it has been conceded that the earlier part of cl. 13, omitting the provisos, constitutes a valid public charitable trust. The circumstance that in selecting the beneficiaries under sub-cl.  a  preference has to be given, under the provisos, to the relations or members of the family of Sir Sasoon David, Bart., cannot affect that public charitable trust.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court, however, took the view that cl. 13 should be read as a whole along with the provisos -and that so read the trust is primarily for the benefit of the relations or members of the family 117 of Sir Sassoon David, Bart. It is pointed out that in applying the net income for the purposes mentioned in sub- cl. a , the trustees are bound, under the first proviso, to give preference to the poor and indigent relations or members of the family of the said Sir Sassoon David, Bart.

arguments.claim: Six purposes in cl.13 are charitable involving public utility; exclusive application to one still exempt under s.4(3)(i)

It was conceded before the High Court- and it has not been disputed before us-that if there was nothing else in this clause, then each of these six purposes would have to be upheld as a charitable purpose involving an element of public utility

arguments.claim: High Court relied on Gordhandas Govindram Family Charitable Trust case where benefit to public was remote

anchor.surface_text: In coming to the decision that it did, the High Court relied on its own earlier decision in the case of Trustees of Gordhandas Govindram Family Charitable Trust v. Commissioner of Income-tax  Central , Bombay  1 . The facts in that case, however, were somewhat different from the facts now before us.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: the earlier part of el. 13, omitting the provisos, companystitutes a valid public charitable trust. The circumstance that in selecting the beneficiar

arguments.court_reasoning: Facts different; present trust not blatant family benefit like Gordhandas

arguments.claim: Primary class test from In re Koettgen's Will Trusts applies: public class ascertained first, preference to sub-class does not invalidate charitable trust

anchor.surface_text: The case of In re Koettgans Will Trusts  1  appears to us, on the facts, to be more in point... Applying this test, there can be no question- indeed it has been conceded that the earlier part of cl. 13, omitting the provisos, constitutes a valid public charitable trust. The circumstance that in selecting the beneficiaries under sub-cl.  a  preference has to be given, under the provisos, to the relations or members of the family of Sir Sasoon David, Bart., cannot affect that public charitable trust.

arguments.claim: Gordhandas case distinguishable as facts show blatant family benefit unlike present trust

anchor.surface_text: The facts in that case, however, were somewhat different from the facts now before us. In that case the trust was significantly enough described as Gordhandas Govindram Family Charitable Trust . Clause 2 of that trust deed provided for the application of the net income in giving help or relief to such poor Vaishyas and other Hindoos as the trustees might consider deserving of help

arguments.claim: Provisos apply only to sub-cl.(a); preference within larger public class of poor/indigent members of communities; family must fit class

anchor.surface_text: We then pass on to the provisos. The first proviso opens with the words in applying the income as aforesaid . This takes us back to sub-cl. a . The meaning of the proviso obviously is that in applying the income for the purpose of sub-cl. a , the trustees shall give preference to the poor and indigent relations or members of the family of Sir Sassoon David, Bart.

holdings.text: In our opinion the income from the trust properties comes within the scope of s. 4 3 i and is, therefore, entitled to exemption. Therefore the negative answer given by the High Court to question No. I cannot be supported and that question should be answered in the affirmative.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion the income from the trust properties comes within the scope of s. 4 3 i and is, therefore, entitled to exemption. Therefore the negative answer given by the High Court to question No. I cannot be supported and that question should be answered in the affirmative.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Clause 13's primary class of beneficiaries under sub-cl. (a) is public (poor and indigent members of communities worldwide); provisos merely direct preference to family relations within that class; applies primary class test from In re Koettgen's Will Trusts; distinguishes Gordhandas as facts differ.

holdings.text: In this view of the matter, question No. 2 does not arise and needs no answer.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Since question 1 answered affirmatively, second question on partial charitable purposes does not arise.

holdings.text: Applying this test, there can be no question- indeed it has been conceded that the earlier part of cl. 13, omitting the provisos, constitutes a valid public charitable trust. The circumstance that in selecting the beneficiaries under sub-cl. a preference has to be given, under the provisos, to the relations or members of the family of Sir Sasoon David, Bart., cannot affect that public charitable trust.

anchor.surface_text: The case of In re Koettgans Will Trusts  1  appears to us, on the facts, to be more in point... Applying this test, there can be no question- indeed it has been conceded that the earlier part of cl. 13, omitting the provisos, constitutes a valid public charitable trust. The circumstance that in selecting the beneficiaries under sub-cl.  a  preference has to be given, under the provisos, to the relations or members of the family of Sir Sasoon David, Bart., cannot affect that public charitable trust.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Adopts primary class test from In re Koettgen's Will Trusts: validity determined at stage of ascertaining primary public class of eligible beneficiaries; subsequent preference direction within class does not invalidate charitable trust.

holdings.text: The first proviso opens with the words in applying the income as aforesaid. This takes us back to sub-cl. a. The meaning of the proviso obviously is that in applying the income for the purpose of sub-cl. a, the trustees shall give preference to the poor and indigent relations or members of the family of Sir Sassoon David, Bart. The proviso does not operate independently but comes into play only in applying the income as aforesaid. The provision for giving preference involves the idea of selection of some persons out of a bigger class envisaged in sub-cl. a.

anchor.surface_text: We then pass on to the provisos. The first proviso opens with the words in applying the income as aforesaid . This takes us back to sub-cl. a . The meaning of the proviso obviously is that in applying the income for the purpose of sub-cl. a , the trustees shall give preference to the poor and indigent relations or members of the family of Sir Sassoon David, Bart.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Provisos linked to and operate only within sub-cl. (a)'s primary public class of poor/indigent community members; family preference requires them to qualify within that class; does not create independent private benefit.

holdings.text: each of these six purposes would have to be upheld as a charitable purpose involving an element of public utility and consequently within the protection of s. 4 3 i. The fact that the trustees could expend the net income on any of the six purposes to the exclusion of the other five purposes would not, it is also conceded, have made the slightest difference in the matter of such exemption from income-tax.

anchor.surface_text: A perusal of cl. 13 of the deed shows that the trust fund is declared to be held by the trustees upon trusts to apply the net income thereof for all or any of the six purposes enumerated therein. It was conceded before the High Court- and it has not been disputed before us-that if there was nothing else in this clause, then each of these six purposes would have to be upheld as a charitable purpose involving an element of public utility

holdings.reasoning_summary: All six purposes in cl. 13(a)-(f) qualify as charitable with public utility element under s.4(3)(i); trustees' discretion to apply exclusively to any one still exempt.

holdings.text: In our judgment, the facts of this case come nearer to the facts of the English case referred to above than to the facts of the earlier decision of the Bombay High Court in Gordhandas Govindram Family Charity Trust case.

anchor.surface_text: In coming to the decision that it did, the High Court relied on its own earlier decision in the case of Trustees of Gordhandas Govindram Family Charitable Trust v. Commissioner of Income-tax  Central , Bombay  1 . The facts in that case, however, were somewhat different from the facts now before us.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Gordhandas Govindram Family Charitable Trust distinguishable: blatant family benefit with remote public element; present trust's primary class public unlike Gordhandas where family prioritized over public class.

anchor.surface_text: The case of In re Koettgans Will Trusts  1  appears to us, on the facts, to be more in point... Applying this test, there can be no question- indeed it has been conceded that the earlier part of cl. 13, omitting the provisos, constitutes a valid public charitable trust. The circumstance that in selecting the beneficiaries under sub-cl.  a  preference has to be given, under the provisos, to the relations or members of the family of Sir Sasoon David, Bart., cannot affect that public charitable trust.

Therefore the negative answer given by the High Court to question No. I cannot be supported and that question should be answered in the affirmative. In this view of the matter, question No. 2 does number arise and

anchor.surface_text: We then pass on to the provisos. The first proviso opens with the words in applying the income as aforesaid . This takes us back to sub-cl. a . The meaning of the proviso obviously is that in applying the income for the purpose of sub-cl. a , the trustees shall give preference to the poor and indigent relations or members of the family of Sir Sassoon David, Bart.

Therefore the negative answer given by the High Court to question No. I cannot be supported and that question should be answered in the affirmative. In this view of the matter, question No. 2 does number arise and
